Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the increase in family health care premiums under President Obama by attributing the entire increase since 2008 to his presidency, when in fact some of the increase occurred during the presidency of George W. Bush.
Falters at times: The claim falters by not accurately attributing the increase in premiums to the correct time period and president.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support because it relies on a single report from the Kaiser Family Foundation without considering other factors or alternative explanations.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the increase in premiums is solely attributable to President Obama's policies, without considering other factors that may have contributed to the increase.
Exist alternative explanation: There may be alternative explanations for the increase in family health care premiums, such as changes in the healthcare industry or economic factors, that are not considered in the claim.
